Once again, Fourier analysis easily illustrate what is going on. When a shock wave is coming, the way to generate such wave shape is to add so many higher frequency harmonics. Suppose, for example, that after 1 micro second, the universe reached 2 light year in diameter. First, that mean the universe expanded about 1 million times the speed of light.
Let's assume that from center to the circumference, we get a concentration of matter that approximate one half cycle of a sinusoidal wave. One half cycle / cycle/microsecond = 500 khz
If that wave has a sharp attack instead of a half sinusoidal, then the harmonics will be 1 mhz, 2 mhz, etc
Brief, an observer standing at 1 light year from the big bang will perceive gravitational waves starting at 1 mhz and extending in upper integer multiples of that fundamental. The intensity of that wave is quite high since the weight of the entire is still concentrated in that expanding sphere

Seems like a good place to share and hopefully discuss an idea about the whole 'universe from nothing' thing.
The idea consists of two assumptions:

First, what we observe as a universe in all it's glory and enormosity appears such, because of OUR scale. And if we assume there was 'nothing' for eternity, and then the Big Bang happend and our universe appeared for SOME TIME, then relatively to the eternal 'nothing' the whole universe...is kinda measly. That assumption kinda eases the whole idea of 'something from nothing', because 'something' is ALMOST 'nothing', and not the great ineffable construct which universe is often referred as.

Second...imagine you took some thing your friend posesses, without asking him, used it and then put it back, so your friend couldn't tell you've ever took it. Basically...if something happened, and then everything returned back, exactly as it was before the event--what changes?

Of course, real objects when used will change in some way, but ideally, what if it was possible to take something and then kind of undo it?
Virtual particles are hypothesized to be a source of the dark energy. They appear from nothing, BUT they appear in pairs and almost always cancel eachother in fraction of a second.
The point is...If something appears from nothing, with a necessary condition for it to be able to disappear sometime afterwards...Then what prevents the object of any level of complexity to emerge from nothingness? Anything can be made from nothing, because it will inevitably return back to nothing, as if nothing happened.
What if the universe appeared kind of as a loan from 'nothingness'?

My personal analogy for a field is the ocean.  If you stand far enough away from the ocean and look at it you can no longer distinguish the individual waves, even though they're still there.  What you can see is when the waves crest.  A cresting waves would represent a photon or an electron in a field even though there's nothing particularly distinct about it. Dark Energy is an unnecessary and unobserved idea. The creation and expansion cycles of the Universe can perfectly be explained with "normal" gravity as we observe it everyday. The Big Bang. A large amount of particles with mass falls through the event horizon of a black hole, residing in our mother universe. This cluster of particles is what constitutes our entire Observable Universe (OU). We are made from some of these particles, living somewhere between that event horizon and the singularity. This cluster of mass (Our OU) continues to accelerate towards the direction of the singularity. Due to Tidal Forces (the fact, thanks Newton, that gravitational force is inversely related to the squared of the distance between two bodies of mass) we observe what appears to be an expanding universe. However, knowing that, matter that is closer to the singularity accelerates away from all matter, which is further. And that this "further matter", in turn accelerates away from all matter that is further than itself. Together with the fact that no two particles in our OU are the same distance from the singularity, we can deduct that all particles in our universe are accelerating away from each other (except for sufficiently dense clusters (Galaxies) that overcome this force (for now)) all in the direction of the singularity. Due to basic Black Hole physics, it is impossible for us to see any light coming from outside our shrinking event horizon (as seen from the "inside"). We call this the Hubble Horizon. Also, because we have no inertial frame outside our OU, we could see at least, we have no clear direction we are heading into, other than time. This explanation also simply accounts for the fact that we observe larger accelerations between more distance parts of our OU. This is due to larger Tidal Forces. Lastly, the schwarzschild radius of a body of mass equivalent to the mass of our OU , is roughly equal to the radius of our OU. So basically yes, we are living inside a Black Hole.
